docs.lead_paragraph: A PIECE in the paper recently told what a punishing burden travel costs have become to sports teams. Inflation has, of course, driven all costs up, the soaring prices of fuel have vastly increased the expense of air travel, and the proliferation of teams and leagues has multiplied distances between playing sites. Up to 1955, the western frontier of the major leagues was St. Louis. Then it moved a few hundred miles to Kansas City, and in 1958 rugged pioneers named Walter O'Malley and Horace Stoneham followed John C. Fremont across the Rockies to California to present baseball to the natives in exchange for colored beads. As the miles stretch out and expenses skyrocket, a simple and desirable remedy has been advocated in this space again and again: Realign the leagues on a geographical basis, not only reducing travel costs but augmenting business at the box office by capitalizing on natural neighborhood rivalries.

headline.main: A Way to Save e Money

docs.lead_paragraph: THE towering intellects of baseball are clanking and groaning and sending up blue curls of smoke as they ponder how to putty up the holes in the split season and playoff plan they swiped so hastily from the bush leagues. It is hoped that if they accomplish it, they adopt by acclamation a resolution of thanks to Counselor Tony LaRussa, the White Sox manager, for calling attention to their bungling. LaRussa was not the first to point out that the split season cum playoffs could encourage hanky-panky on the field, but he was the first listened to by the men who own baseball. As early as Aug. 9, these words appeared in this space: ''If the split season invites some genteel cheating and refined goldbricking, the men who voted for it will blame the players.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Add to the chorus of baseball's ancients crying out against the 'softness' of modern baseball the voice of Jack Zalusky, star catcher for the New York Yankees and Chicago Cubs 30 years ago. ''Modern diamond athletes are 'babied too much for their own good,' says Zalusky, now a guard at a Minneapolis bank. 'Nowadays when a player gets some minor injury they immediately drag him off to a hospital. In my day, when someone got hurt they just wrapped a rag around his wound and he kept right on playing.' '' 'And not only that,' Zalusky adds, 'too much care is taken to see that they don't get overworked. When I broke into organized ball with Louisville in 1900, I caught 174 games without losing an inning. That was in spite of various split fingers and spike cuts.

headline.main: The Days When Men Were Men

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY asked Jim Frey what his feelings had been when George Brett hit the ball. ''My feeling was that we were going to the World Series,'' said the manager of the Kansas City Royals, champions of the American League. The pennant playoff was over. The New York Yankees, back in their accustomed October berth at the top of the American League East after lending those digs to the Baltimore Orioles, had gone all soft and sweet and subservient in three consecutive encounters with Kansas City, the opponent they had beaten for the pennant in 1976, 1977 and 1978. George Brett, the marvelous hitter who fell 10 points short of batting .400 this year, had wrapped up the third and deciding playoff game, 4-2, with a three-run home run against Rich Gossage, the frightening relief pitcher.

docs.lead_paragraph: DURING the baseball strike, Ray Grebey, the one and only spokesman for the club owners' player relations committee, had a line he found occasion to drop in with a sneer. ''Well,'' he would say, ''now we have a strike over three players.'' He meant that if the owners won their demand for professional compensation for free agents, only three players would have to be paid for with other players out of major league organizations. The 1981 crop of free agents went on the market Friday, and only three qualified as Type A players demanding professional compensation. So choirboys in the Grebey chorus are singing: ''That long, costly strike for three players.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Portugal beat Tampa Bay for the third time this season and Mike Stanley homered in Boston's 4-2 victory last night in St. Petersburg, Fla. Portugal (5-6) went six innings, allowing two runs and seven hits, to improve to 3-0 in four starts against the Devil Rays. Tim Wakefield pitched a perfect ninth for his ninth save. Tampa Bay stranded nine men and went 1-for-12 with runners in scoring position against Portugal and Derek Lowe, who struck out Jose Canseco and Fred McGriff to get out of a jam in the seventh.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox defeat Tampa Bay Devil Rays, 4-2, St Petersburg, Fla; roundup of other American League results (S)
